the blind beggar BOY LEADING ILLUGI

set.p: The scene is laid in the district of Skagafirth , in the North of Iceland . The action takes place during the winter previous to the battle of Hunafloi , 1244 A. D .

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: So-called ‘ Little Hall ’ in BRAND 'S manor-house at Reynistad . Enter the DEACON SIGURD , THOROLF BJARNASON , ALF OF GROF , and EINAR THE RICH , of Vik .

sp.speaker: Deacon Sigurd
sp.p: — Thorolf , Lady Jorun bade you wait here until her husband comes .

lg.l: — Where is Brand Kolbeinsson ? I bear a message for him from my
Lord Kolbein the Young .

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — Why comes he not himself ?

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — Kolbein is nigh unto d ——

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Are you garrulous again , Alf ?

lg.l: — He lies sick with his wound , I ween .
Thorolf and Alf
Einar the Rich
— That news I ought to bring secretly to
Thord Kakali .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Why will Lady Jorun not speak to her guests ?

lg.l: — She bade me say that she had seen you last , Thorolf
Bjarnason , at such business that she cares not to see you any more .
Thorolf
— Last I saw her at the slaying of Kalf
Guttormsson , her father , and of Guttorm , her brother .

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — Much good reason has my lady if she cares to see you no more .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — You are the man who most egged on to the deed , that father and son should be slain .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — No , Urækja it was , the son of Snorri Sturlason . A most useful deed it was . Ever since Kolbein 's men have obeyed his commands without gainsaying .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — More useful still , I suppose you think that you snatched from out of Kalf 's hands the crucifix he held when kneeling to receive the mortal stroke .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — His blood would have spurted on the cross , had it been held so near .Wrathfully .And likewise would I do to you , Einar the Rich , if Kolbein struck off your head . Your wife is a kinswoman of Thord Kakali , and dreamt have I that you will find an earlier grave than will I .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — An evil business it is to threaten me with death . No one knows who will be buried first . A faithful follower of Kolbein I have been .

lg.l: — ‘ Scarce shall I trust you ,
Troll , quoth Haustkoll . ’

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — Wicked speech this is and witless .

div.stage: Enter BRAND KOLBEINSSON , BRODDI THORLEIFSSON , HELGI SKAFTASON , and others .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — You here , Thorolf Bjarnason ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Ay , sir ; and with a message for you , for Broddi , and for other chieftains , from Kolbein the Young .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Is it that Thord Kakali is expected from the West with war ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Not to my knowledge . He is still busy drinking the arvel after Tumi his brother , whom we put to death this last week !

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — Yes , and he and his men are now drinking the ale by the bowlful , they say .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — What of it , if Thord does give his men in plenty ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — And why should we not speak of it , we who know what folly it is for men to drink heavily before going to war ?

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — A generous chieftain is Thord Kakali , and likely to accomplish great deeds . No chieftain in this land has ever lost so many men as has he . It is not seeming to make sport of his sorrow .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — None have I ever seen flee so fast as these men of Thord 's , they urge each other on to flight .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Idle speech is this , Thorolf !

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — I say what I will , and care not whether others like it or no .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Where is the message my brother-in-law sends us ? Thorolfhanding the letter to BRAND— I have lived all my life in warfare and am not able to read . Brandhanding the letter to DEACON SIGURD— Read for us , deacon ! Einar the Richwhile SIGURD is undoing the strings with which the parchment is tied , aside to ALF OF GROF— I know you are no friend of Thorolf ; stay behind here and help me to persuade Brand Kolbeinsson . Alfaside to EINAR THE RICH— Broddi and all of Thorolf 's neighbors hate him because he elbows himself forward ruthlessly . Against my will I left my home with Thorolf ; but how shall I help you ? Einaraside to ALF— Help me dye Thorolf 's white coat of mail as red as blood . Alfaside— Hush ! We would have to fight against great odds . Einaraside— Not if Brand Kolbeinsson were on our side . Alfaside— Brand — indeed ! No , if Broddi Thorleifsson were with us . Sigurdhas now untied the parchment , reads— ‘ To Brand Kolbeinsson of Stad , to Broddi Thorleifsson , to Kolbein Kaldaljos , and to Paul Kolbeinsson , Kolbein Arnorsson of Flugumyr sends God 's greetings and his own . Little we know of Thord Kakali 's affairs after Easter . After the slaying of his brother Tumi it is but likely that he is preparing for war against us , and in such case , if he came upon us from the West , we of the North Quarter would want to subject him to a severe test . But now it is so ill with our health that we may no longer conceal it from you . Because of this it is our will that all of you meet me here as soon as possible . Only in this wise may we prevent the danger now threatening both the entire quarter and our district . ’

lg.l: — To what danger to the district does the letter refer ? Is
Kinsman Kolbein sick anew , then ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Answer that yourself ; but well may these words mean that it were better now to take off the ‘ velvet glove ’ and bestir one 's hands . Brandangrily— Get you gone , Thorolf , at once ! Astonishing it is that you should be sent hither to Stad , such enemies as we two have been .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — My course I shall steer wheresoever it take me , whether or no you like it , Brand Kolbeinsson . To horse , yeoman Alf !

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — Unwillingly I followed you , Thorolf , and left my farm work behind . Take with you the two companions that always have followed you — death and the devil !

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Right , you insolent fool , death has ever been my companion .BRAND KOLBEINSSON goes to the door and opens it .Now you precede me to the door , Brand Kolbeinsson , for higher-born than I you are . But in all tests of manhood , in assemblies and in battles , I have gone before you . There is no danger in going before me now ; it is quite safe !Exit .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — An astonishing thing it is that base men should dare to speak in such wise to chieftains !

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — He is a greater friend of my kinsman Kolbein than any other man .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — And in greater favor even with Lady Helga than with Kolbein .

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — He journeyed to Rome with Kolbein . Such a pilgrimage atones for many a sin .

div.stage: Enter LADY JORUN with her and BRAND 'S sons , KALF and THORGEIR .

sp.speaker: Jorun
sp.p: — What errand brought Thorolf Bjarnason hither to Stad ?

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Kolbein the Young sent him .

sp.speaker: Jorun
sp.p: — Then we shall have to put up with that insult .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — Your husband he called a ‘ velvet glove ! ’

sp.speaker: Jorun
sp.p: — Gentle have his hands ever been to me , and I might well call him so .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — And a coward he called him .

sp.speaker: Jorun
sp.p: — Slower he is to ill deeds than Thorolf .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — Me Thorolf threatened with death , and to wrench out of my hands the crucifix , whenever I should lie down for the blow , just as he did to Kalf Guttormsson . Jorunmoved to tears— Was that done to my father ?

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — It was indeed done to him , and a mighty ill deed it was .

sp.speaker: Jorun
sp.p: — I had not thought that men who were to lose their lives would be thus cruelly dealt with .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — These men have indeed done enough to forfeit their lives , and ought to live no longer .

sp.speaker: Helgi Skaftason
sp.p: — If no one can be prevailed upon to kill them I shall undertake it .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — No one 's duty it is as much as yours , Brand Kolbeinsson , to take revenge for the murder of Kalf Guttormsson .

sp.speaker: Jorun
sp.p: — Let no one be so bold as to seek revenge for my father . Full composition did Kolbein the Young pay for reconciliation , after the death of father and son , with the fine of hundred marks silver , which were paid out to my mother and me as stipulated .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — And yet might Brand and others take revenge for the wrongs they have suffered at the hands of Thorolf , even though Kalf Guttormsson 's death be atoned for .

sp.speaker: Jorun
sp.p: — Do not undertake so dangerous an enterprise , my husband . Well you know that if you slay Thorolf his friend Kolbein will slay you all in revenge .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — Kolbein lies nigh unto death .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Is his condition so dangerous ?

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Why , have you not told news so important and so — sad until now ?

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — I could not , on account of Thorolf . Kolbein holds his malady secret as long as he can .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Then my kinsman Kolbein must have summoned us to dispose of his dominions before he dies .

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — That is , all the North Quarter and the Westfirths !

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — About the Westfirths we have been at war until now .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — And his heir ?All look at BRAND .They say that it is the wish of Lady Helga to set Thorolf Bjarnason over all the dominions .

sp.speaker: Many
sp.p: — Thorolf Bjarnason ?

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — Impossible !

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — It would mean the death of one man or many men .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Helgi Skaftason , have the saddles laid upon twelve horses ! I and eleven men shall ride forthwith to Flugumyr .Exit HELGI .

sp.speaker: Kalf
sp.p: — Lay saddle on my horse also . I shall ride to Flugumyr to my foster-mother .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — What will you of her , my young fellow ?

sp.speaker: Kalf
sp.p: — I want to get the weapons she has promised to give me .

sp.speaker: Jorun
sp.p: — No weapons , Kalf ! You will not go to Flugumyr , this time ; rather too long you have been there as a child .Towards BRAND KOLBEINSSON .My husband , remember my words . To kill one of my kinsman Kolbein 's or Lady Helga 's men is to conjure up odds against you , whatever be the provocation .Exit with the boys .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Never shall that come to pass that a man of low birth govern so large a dominion .Exeunt all .

div.head: SCENE II
div.stage: Room at Flugumyr . LADY HELGA and the woman physician SALVOR enter .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — I have much to do about the house and can attend the patient but little . How is my husband , Salvor ?

lg.l: — Rather poorly ! He is now confessing to Bishop Botolf , Lady
Helga .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Confessing ? Did he speak about the disposition of his dominions after his death ?

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — The bishop touched upon that , but Kolbein said that this would have to wait until his kinsmen were assembled .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — To what purpose is the advice of his kinsmen in that matter ? I see how it will end .

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — I have hopes that your husband will again recover his health this time .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — And how long will he keep it then ?

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — So long as he stirs not .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — My husband will have to go to war and do battle as long as he lives .

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — Now he longs for peace .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Then is he surely sick !Vehemently .My husband must not be sick ; he will have to speak with his kinsmen , when they come . Give him strong drugs that he may have strength to do so . His sickness must not become known in the Westfirths by Thord Kakali .

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — Such strong drugs are not without danger .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — What danger is there in them ?

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — That he loses possession of his senses , and becomes even more sick thereafter . Helgavehemently— His kinsmen must not know that he is sick , or else they will take matters in their own hands . He will have to have drugs so strong as to give him strength to hold council with them .

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — But if he loses possession of his senses during it ? Helgawith a look of relief— Let me take care of that . Then I shall speak for him , for all his intentions are known to me .

lg.l: — My advice it is not to use strong drugs ; they may endanger
Kolbein 's life .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Will you , low-born woman , give advice to a great ?

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — Why seek you then a low-born woman to heal the great ?

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — I knew none better . Do as I bid you !

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — I shall do as you bid , my lady . You run the risk , not I .

div.stage: Enter THOROLF .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Hail , lady ! How is the chieftain 's health ?

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Rather good ! Salvor says he will not be able to bear going into war for the first .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Kolbein has a-plenty of men to lead his troops .

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — Brand Kolbeinsson —

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — He , the velvet glove ! Whilst Kolbein was on his foray to Reykholar and slew Tumi — a feat now famous — Brand was to dispatch old Sturla Thordsson — the fellow who mostly goes about with ink on his fingers . But Sturla gulled him so that Brand had to return with shame . Brand lacks both forethought before battle and that fire in battle which wins the victory .

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — Brand Kolbeinsson is a man of peace .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — You shall stay here at Flugumyr now , Thorolf , whilst my husband is in ill health . Brand Kolbeinsson would be but a low wall between us and Thord Kakali , should he advance from the West .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — So long have I been one of your household , my lady , that I am bound to obey . But who shall take care of the shipbuilding which I have under way for Kolbein the Young ?

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Your wife Arnfrid ; for this is not a place for women to be at .

lg.l: — The ships that are to be used for carrying our war into the
Westfirths this spring ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Yes . This spring we shall lay waste the Westfirths , kill cattle and people , burn down storehouses , farms , and churches , and slay all men we overtake . Thord shall not be able to hold himself there thereafter .

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — Holy mother of God ! Why are the people to suffer all that misery and affliction ! Have there not been enough maimings and killings in the Westfirths ? Be mindful , Thorolf , that you , too , may be taken captive and your bright coat of mail get a red collar .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Often have I thought of it . But he who lets himself be kept back by such thoughts had better never venture into danger .

lg.l: — Go now , Salvor , and attend to the patient !
The life of my husband is in great danger !

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: coming close to her— And shall I then become the Lord of Eyafirth ? Helgamotioning him away— Kolbein the Young still lives . Whilst he is living the disposition of the dominions remains his matter . It may well be , though , that I succeed in making him give you Eyafirth , and then more people from here would settle there than are there now . Then I shall foster up young Kalf , the son of Brand , because he will inherit Skagafirth from his father ; and while he is young , and I gain influence over him , it may happen that the men of Skagafirth and Eyafirth would work in unison in all undertakings , and rule the entire country alone .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Certainly ! Certainly !

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Swear allegiance to me , Thorolf !

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — I have ever been faithful to you .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Will you be obedient to me , Thorolf ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Yes , gladlykisses her hand, now as always before . Helgagently— You have always been true to me , and that shall be rewarded as soon as ever I can .

div.stage: Enter BRAND KOLBEINSSON , BRODDI , DEACON SIGURD , EINAR THE RICH , ALF , HELGI SKAFTASON , together with six others .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Hail , lady !

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Hail , my nephew ! Hail , all of you ! My husband has been expecting you with impatience . Einaraside— Now we shall see how sick a man Kolbein is .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — We pray you all to say the least possible about the infirmity of my husband ; I have no more than sixty armed men about me .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — And who is their leader ?

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Thorolf Bjarnason , Asbjorn Illugason , and Haf Bjarnason .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — And Thorolf Bjarnason remains here ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — First I shall return to my estate to give orders as to my affairs . Helgaaside to THOROLF— You speak incautiously , to tell them where you mean to go . I read your death in their eyes .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — You will not refuse me to keep you company on the way home ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — No ; I care not to have your company , you insolent fool !

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — You will remain here with us , Thorolf , on account of the infirmity of my husband and our defencelessness otherwise ; you can send some one else to arrange matters on your estate .

div.stage: LADY HELGA and those about her exeunt by door . BRODDI , ALF , and EINAR THE RICH remain behind in the foreground .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Lady Helga has become suspicious of us .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — Sharp are the eyes of my Lady Helga whenever Thorolf is concerned .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — He has slipped from our grasp , the hellhound !

div.stage: KOLBEIN THE YOUNG , pale and weak , is borne in on shields by ASBJORN ILLUGASON , HAF BJARNASON , and others . BISHOP BOTOLF and SALVOR enter with them .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Hail to you all !

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Pax vobiscum !They bow to KOLBEIN and the BISHOP . KOLBEIN is borne to the high seat . HELGA stands beside him , also SALVOR keeps near him always .Brandcoming forward— How stands matters with you , kinsman Kolbein ?

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Not so very well . Broddicoming forward— You have but a small body-guard about you to-day , brother-in-law ! Kolbeinpointing to BISHOP BOTOLF— This body-guard alone has been sufficient for some time .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — You have summoned us to meet you .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — I wanted , with the assistance of my kinsmen and of others , to make such provisions for our dominions as would most likely result in peace for the district .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Peace we should desire for every consideration , since many regions are beginning to grow poor .

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — The wars have fanned into flame hatred and malice over all the land .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Blessed are the peacemakers !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — During these last days the deep wound I received in the battle of Orlygsstad has been troubling me sorely , and I am so exhausted that I often look forward to death . Now you well know that Thord Kakali has lost through me both father and five brothers . That stands in the way of peace in the district . I therefore offer to go abroad and give up all my dominions .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Give up all dominions !

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — And yield them to King Hakon ?

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — If King Hakon should lay claim to my lands I should give him six feet of land , or so much less as he lacks in height . To give Iceland to him is as bad as yielding up one 's soul to the devil .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — But who is to receive the lands ?

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — I shall give all my dominions to Thord Kakali , and thus atone for the killing of his father and brothers . Your own cases would then be at his mercy . I expect that you will fare well in this , because just then did Thord prove to be my best friend when I entrusted my matters entirely to him ; at that time you were also on friendly terms , you and the men from Skagafirth .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — That would be a disposition promising peace , if the king himself is not to receive the dominion .Aside .It is the same as if King Hakon did receive it .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — You will deprive me of my rightful inheritance , and give up all your dominions to Thord ! Then will I rather fight for them until I fall .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Thord may think he has so much to settle with us that we could not endure the punishments he would inflict upon us — that is , if we had any desire to do so .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — If all dominions were given up to Thord he would treat us well .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — And then there would be peace on earth and good-will among men .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — In Thord 's Hall all we , your men , would have to sit upon the lower bench . His men whom we have pursued , wounded , stripped of their clothes , and beaten whenever we engaged them , they would take revenge on us , under cover of him . All of us desire but one of two things , to do battle until we gain peace , or else , to fall with such renown as is granted us .

sp.speaker: Asbjorn
sp.p: — We will follow no other man whilst you live . The followers of Kolbein .— No , no other man !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Then your other choice is that all yeomen at their own expense guard in four parties the frontier during the remainder of winter . The first will have to be on the Skagafirth , to guard the road over the Kjol and the ways leading from Storasand . The second guard will have to be in Vididale , Vatnsdale , and Nupsdale to watch the paths over the Grimstungu-heath , and the one over Tvidægra-heath . The third and fourth guards will have to be in Midfirth and Hrutafirth , and to protect the ways along the Holtavordu-heath , and those from the Dales and Strands . When the sea is safe two light-sailing vessels will have to be sent around the Skaw to reconnoitre the sea-way toward the west .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Well , you have thought out everything , brother-in-law ; to me this plan of war seems in every regard the best .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — If it is followed , Thord will never return west alive over the Blanda River , should he attack us .

sp.speaker: Asbjorn
sp.p: — Thord will be able to get over the Kjol Mountains or the Sprengisand Desert , down to the Eyafirth . There he will call upon his friends and attack us in the flank .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — That is unthinkable . In order to reach either of these ways Thord would have to journey around the whole island , and then overcome Hjalti the bishop 's son , and Gissur 's men . I should think it likeliest that Hjalti would flee north over the Kjol should he be defeated , and come our way some little time before Thord , who would have to go by a farther way and would waste his time in getting the men of Eyafirth to rise . Kolbein 's plan of war is the best that can be chosen .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — It is most often Thorolf Bjarnason who best comprehends my plans . Broddiaside , clinching his hand against his breast— Does he understand them best ?

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — All shall be done as you bid , kinsman Kolbein . I myself shall send three hundred men as guard into Hunathing .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Then all is well , kinsman Brand !

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — You speak too much , my lord !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — I must speak to-day ; to-day to-morrow is not sure to meto the othersThe third matter is the apportionment of the districts after my death .

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — Speaking irritates your wound , my lord , and you may become delirious .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Let come what may ! I will that my kinsman Brand have Skagafirth and Hunathing after my death . But Eyafirth and all districts east of the Heath I give to —He becomes delirious . Lady HELGA makes a motion and stops him .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — See , wife , now fly the swans from Holar in Hjaltadale . Botolfto DEACON SIGURD— He is dreaming about the messengers of the Holy Church , the sick man ! Sigurdto BISHOP BOTOLF— He will not live till to-morrow 's matins ! Helgabending down over KOLBEIN— Appoint Thorolf Bjarnason !

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Who is to get Eyafirth ?

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — I heard no one named .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — I name you , Thorolf Bjarnason !

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — For what do you name Thorolf Bjarnason ?

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — For the chieftainship over Eyafirth and all districts north of the Heath .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — I claim that I have better title to it than Thorolf .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — It will prove a troublesome business for you to wrench Eyafirth out of my hands .In a whisper to HELGA , to whom he has approached more closely .Am I given Eyafirth then ? Helgawhispers back— Do not let it be seen that you are whispering to me . They will become suspicious . My position is difficult .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — I shall spare you , kinsman !Speaks unintelligibly . HELGA bends down over him .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — My husband wishes that you , Brand Kolbeinsson , and you , Thorolf , shall swear to each other an everlasting truce , now immediately .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Is that your wish , kinsman Kolbein ?

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — It is . It is . Six hundred men ! Advance bravely after me ! My kinsman Brand is in great danger .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Always it is you , Brand ! Physician , attend to the sick man .

sp.speaker: Salvor
sp.p: — Carry your chieftain into his bed !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Woden owns all the slain men ! Neither Thord Kakali nor one of his men will return alive over Blanda . Another battle won . A great and glorious victory . Carry away the fallen , I will not see them . Woden owns all the slain men .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — So much devilish magic yet living in a Christian country ! And this man have I shriven but a short while ago ! Woden owns all the slain men !KOLBEIN 'S men surround him to bear him out on their shields . HELGA speaks fast and in a low voice to ASBJORN ILLUGASON .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Place our armed servants before all doors . And let them stay there . And leave the doors open after you when you come in again .

lg.l: — Woden owns all the slain men . You bleed , Thorolf Bjarnason .
Put on your head , Thorolf ! Put on your head ! Beware of the cave by the
Kolbeinstream !

div.stage: ASBJORN ILLUGASON , HAF , and others carry KOLBEIN out . SALVOR follows them . HELGA leads BISHOP BOTOLF to the high seat .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — I have neglected to show you those marks of esteem which I ought to have shown you , my lord ! But my situation has been a troublesome one for a while .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — I have been thinking in my mind the while , my lady , how much you resemble in mien and carriage the women of the ancient race of the kings of Norway . Helgalaughs— I am a descendant in the fourth generation of King Magnus Bareleg , and were I a man and not a woman I would be nearer to the throne of Norway than your King Hakon . This relationship cost my brother Paul his life , when he was in Norway .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — That story I have heard ! But his death was not the wish of the Norwegians .

div.stage: ASBJORN and HAF , and the men who carried out KOLBEIN , come in again , leaving the door stand open . One sees armed men standing outside . LADY HELGA seats herself on the dais .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — How long shall my husband wait until you swear the truce to each other , Thorolf and Brand ?

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — The Holy Church cannot confirm the apportionment of the districts which you have made , excepting the chieftains swear each other an everlasting truce .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — The Holy Church owns not the Northland Quarter !

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — But God does ; and do you for his sake as Kolbein and the lady bid you , because that promises best for peace . Helgavery loud— Close the door !All look to the door and perceive the armed men ; it is closed .Haf Bjarnason will pronounce for you the words of the truce . The truce which his namesake established between the men of Skagafirth and Grettir Asmundarson was well kept , and it redounded to their honor . Broddiaside to BRAND— Agree to the truce ! Sixty armed men are standing but a few feet away !

div.stage: BRAND KOLBEINSSON places himself in the left foreground , with six of his men behind him . HAF behind him in the middle ground . THOROLF advances to the right foreground , posturing himself opposite BRAND .

sp.speaker: Asbjorn
sp.p: — Are we to be witnesses , Thorolf ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — All those present shall be witnesses !

div.stage: ASBJORN and five others arrange themselves behind him .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — In Oddi , at my father Sæmund 's , I heard that those oaths were void which were made against one 's free will .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — I shall swear a truce to Brand Kolbeinsson of my own free will .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — And you , kinsman Brand ?BRAND looks toward the door and says nothing .Helgastamps her foot on the floor of the dais , whereupon the door opens slowly , and swords and spears become visible— And you , Brand Kolbeinsson ?

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — I shall swear a truce to Thorolf with a willing mind . But what are the conditions , and for what offence the fine ?

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Thorolf Bjarnason shall make atonement for having , in my hearing and in the presence of other men , given Brand Kolbeinsson a nickname ; he shall pay for his offence with the ring which he wears on his arm and which weighs six ounces . Is this offer of reconciliation a good one ? Brand and Thorolf .— Indeed a good one ! Helgataking a large ring off her arm and holding it between her fingers— Pronounce , then , the pledge of truce , Haf — according to our laws ! Hafsets a little table between them and stands beside it . Receives the ring from THOROLF , holds it in one hand , and a parchment in the other , and pronounces the pledge of truce in an impressive manner— Contention there has been between Brand Kolbeinsson and Thorolf Bjarnason . But now is this contention no more , a fine has been paid according to the decision of good and noble men , of full weight , and good metal , and handed over to him to whom it is due . But if contention there should arise again between them , then shall they settle by fee , and not by reddened steel . But if one of these parties become so bereft of his senses that he break this reconciliation , and pledge of truce , or becomes the contriver of the other 's death , then shall he be driven from God , and from the commerce of all Christendom , as far as men pursue wolves , Christians visit churches , heathen men sacrifice in temples , mothers bear children , children say mother , fire burns , ships sail , shields flash , the sun shines , snow lies , pines grow , the falcon flies the long spring day , with a fair wind under both his wings . He shall shun churches and Christian people , the house of God and the houses of men , and the abodes of men , and every home but hell .HAF lays the ring on the parchment , which he holds between them . They lay each their right hand on the book .Both of you with your hands touch one book , and even on it lies the fine with which Thorolf atones for his offence , for himself and for his heirs , conceived or unconceived , born or unborn , baptized or unbaptized ; and in return he receives from Brand Kolbeinsson assurances of eternal and everlasting truce , a truce which shall persist the while the earth lasts and men live .Silence . BRAND KOLBEINSSON takes the ring off the book and puts it on his arm , whilst HAF lays the book on the table again .Now you , Brand Kolbeinsson and Thorolf Bjarnason , shall be men reconciled and agreeing , wherever you meet , whether on land or on sea , on ship or on ski , on sea or on horseback , on bench or on thwart ; and if need be , divide between you oar and scoop , knife and piece of meat ; shall be at one with each other as is father with son , or son with father . Join hands nowthey grasp each the other 's handand stand by your truce according to the will of Christ and all those men who now have heard your pledge of faith . May he have the grace of God who keeps the truce , but his wrath he who breaks it . Let this be a full reconciliation between you , and let us be witnesses who are present .

div.stage: THOROLF approaches HELGA , who gives him the ring she had been holding ; He puts it on his arm , without anybody noticing it but her . BISHOP BOTOLF walks up to her . The ranks of the witnesses mix , BRAND and BRODDI station themselves in the foreground .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — A great work and one sorely needed have you performed to-day , my lady . Assuredly more than small good fortune it is to have reconciled two such men whom Kolbein the Young never could prevail upon to become reconciled , as we are told . Helgasmiling— The granddaughter of Ion Loftsson of Oddi ought to have sufficient good fortune to reconcile by her sole efforts men who both are her friends . Brandaside to BRODDI— May it never be avenged on Lady Helga to have cowed me by overwhelming force to promise an eternal truce to my worst foe . Broddito BRAND— But a short while will the hand rejoice over the blow !CurtainACT II

div.stage: A cave by KOLBEIN 's stream . The stage represents a small vale with the cave in the background . The cave is large and deep , opening in the direction of the spectator . Water has been coursing down the vale and has frozen to knolls of ice here and there . A part of the cave-mouth is hidden by icicles formed by the water trickling from the rock above the cave . Snow is falling heavily and drifting . This continues throughout the act .
BRAND KOLBEINSSON , BRODDI , ALF , DEACON SIGURD , HELGI SKAFTASON , EINAR THE RICH , and six others enter .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — A cursed ill weather this !

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — The great drift-ice must be near !

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — But there is shelter in this cave here , and here we shall stay awhile .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — A witch-storm this is , and we have lost our way !

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — The weather is cold and fit for men . We would do well to use our stay here for coming to an agreement about our attack on Thorolf Bjarnason ; because home he journeyed , even if Lady Helga assured us to the contrary .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — Let us make away with the new chief of the Eyafirthings !

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — For me it is not seeming to be in this undertaking , having sworn an eternal truce to Thorolf .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — But none of us others have .

sp.speaker: Helgi Skaftason
sp.p: — I am not your slave , Brand Kolbeinsson ; and if I may not avenge the insults Thorolf has inflicted on you , I shall no longer be your follower , either .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — All your men will desert you , if you permit them not to avenge you on Thorolf .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — What would men say if my followers broke a pledged truce ?

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — A truce under compulsion it was , with sixty men , but a few steps away .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — Slight is your recollection concerning the murder of Kalf the son of Guttorm !

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — It is better to suffer than to do ill .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — It is seeming to a chieftain to commit deeds of injustice and highhandedness , so soon as need be for them ; but not to suffer them of others .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — What need is there that we kill Thorolf Bjarnason now rather than before ?

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — He is now set as lord over Eyafirth . He is our enemy , and as it is the Eyafirthings have grievances against us .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — For their shameful defeat at Orlygsstad and the fall of their chieftains .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — The Eyafirthings will assail us from the east under Thorolf , and Thord Kakali from the west . The henchmen of Lady Helga will stand by Thorolf , and not by you , Brand .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — But Gissur Thorvaldsson will come to my help over the mountains from the south .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — An ill thing , to have Gissur as one 's only friend . He is no warrior , keeps no promise , and dares not to fight .

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — Never rely on Gissur 's valor !

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — He is a coward !

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — None of you mentions what is of most importance . Lady Helga it was , and not Kolbein the Young , who assigned Eyafirth to Thorolf .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — That is a lie , Einar !

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — Kolbein had become delirious when Helga asserted Eyafirth was given to Thorolf .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — That , indeed , is the truth .

sp.speaker: Several
sp.p: — Yes , that indeed is the truth .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Does she mean to arrange the districts ? If so , we mean to make away with Thorolf . You shall have no hand in this , Brand Kolbeinsson , but your men shall follow me .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — And who is to follow me ?

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — No one !

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — That was the cause of my kinsman Kolbein 's greatness that all his men obeyed him without a murmur . No one obeys me now !

lg.l: — But this obedience came first about after the fall of Kalf
Guttormsson .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — No need to remind me again that Thorolf was the foremost instigator to the killing of him .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Let us then seize Thorolf , wherever we may find him , and slay him . Allexcept BRAND— Yes , let us slay him !

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Or else let us surround his house and lead him out to be put to death .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — Oh , let him perish in the flames of his own house . Sigurd — For shame , Alf ! I do not care to share the torments of hell with incendiaries .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Kolbein the Young will surely take revenge on us for his friend Thorolf .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — Kolbein is no longer to be reckoned among living men .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Kinsman Kolbein lay more sorely stricken with his wound this time than last , and even then was in danger of his life .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — I cannot tell a doomed man if he ever arises again .

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — A great loss it would be if a chieftain so noble and so beloved should depart this world .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — And one so victorious !

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — Let us pray for his soul !

div.stage: Silence . All present show marks of grief and of praying .

lg.l: — But you will lend us your aid , Brand , after the slaying of
Thorolf , and will take steps to make Lady Helga leave the district ?
— It is not seeming that I give counsel to those who plan
Thorolf 's death .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — We shall help you to obtain all the dominions in Skagafirth and west as far as Hrutafirth for it ; because it is not so very sure whether all are willing to accept you as overlord .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — I thank you , friend Broddi . But I shall take no part in your dealings with Thorolf . Afterwards I shall not part from you .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — Let us touch our weapons to confirm it , according to Norse custom !

sp.speaker: Many
sp.p: — Yes , let us brandish weapons ! Broddimounting a rock— We , Alf of Grof , Broddi Thorleifsson , Einar the Rich , and all who are here , excepting only Brand Kolbeinsson , agree , and brandish our weapons in confirmation of our purpose , that we shall not part from one another , and share a common fate , until we shall have brought from life to death Thorolf Bjarnason .

div.stage: All , except BRAND , lift their weapons and strike their shields with their swords .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — And remember then , Broddi , what you promised me !

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — We all who are assembled here promise and brandish our weapons in confirmation thereof , to aid Brand Kolbeinsson to gain dominion over Skagafirth and west as far as Hrutafirth , after the death of Kolbein the Young ; he on his part promises to support us with all his might in the action against us for the killing of Thorolf Bjarnason .

div.stage: All raise their weapons and clash them against their shields , BRAND likewise .

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — The weather has been clearing up this while .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Who will now seek the way and go before us ?

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Alf Gudmundsson of Grof .They depart .The stage is empty for a while , the snow begins to fall and drift again . Of a sudden , JARNGRIM is seen to stand in the cave . He has a spear in his hand and is tall and of strong frame . He wears a wide cloak with the hood down over his eyes . He has a long beard . As soon as he appears two ravens settle over the mouth of the cave and disappear with him . [ A)Footnote A : In Norse mythology Woden ( Odinis represented as one-eyed . Else , his attributes are those described here . ] Jarngrimleans on his spear and calls out— Thorolf ! Thorolffrom without— All 's well , companions , I heard a human voice !Silence .

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — Thorolf ! Thorolffrom without— Where are you ?

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — Here ! Thorolfand two others enter .. THOROLF 'S men never see JARNGRIM . They kindle a fire forthwith— What is your name , friend ?

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — Jarngrim I am called .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — We have lost our way . Will you allow me to sit down at the fire ?

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — There is a plenty of dry fuel in the cave .

div.stage: THOROLF 'S men have been kindling the fire which burns up brightly . JARNGRIM nods to THOROLF .

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — This eve we shall drink mead together !

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — And no houses hereabouts ?With arising suspicion .How many are there of you ?

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — Never have I had a companion , except my horse and two hawks . Thorolfpoints to the ravens , mockingly— Your hawks are of a black color , likely ; they are sitting there near enough to you .

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — Near they sit to me , whenever good prey is near .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Who has made you an outlaw ?

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — The White Christ .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Excommunicated then you are ! Bishop Botolf will absolve you if you confess to him your troubles .

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — Never would Botolf admit me to church if he knew who I am .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Give some of your property to the church for absolution .

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — The temples of the White God have taken possession of all my goods , except my horse and my hawks ,— we four still journey together .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Become my follower and accompany me to Eyafirth , if Kolbein the Young dies .

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — Kolbein the Young will not die . But to be your man , Thorolf , I care not , because you pursue your ends to excess , small means as you have . It will never end well .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — How can you know that , you who are ignorant of all ?

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — An old man knows that a man 's character is his destiny .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Go then and serve Kolbein the Young if he lives .

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — Oft was I a follower of Kolbein .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — How may that be , then , that I know you not ?

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — The haughty heed not though they see a sage . Most men knew me in former times , but few know me now . Small has become the number of my friends .

lg.l: — Now I recognize you , friend . I saw you in the battle of
Orlygsstad , when you stood over the corpse of Sighvat Sturluson .

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — A great friend of mine was Sighvat .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — And a short time ago , when you stood over the body of Tumi Sighvatsson , at Reykholar . You turned your back to the church . And whither are you journeying now ?

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — Thither where tidings are near . Whenever I come down the mountain side there arises tumult in the valleys ; wherever I remain all day great battles are fought . The Norns have decreed all that . But now men say that the White God is about to come from the south , with great splendor , and that he will bring with him peace . I ween it will prove a lie .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Decreed by the Norns ! You must be an old man ?

lg.l: — I was Ingolf 's the First Settler 's pilot on his journey to
Iceland .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — I am not a book-learned man ; yet must you , then , be exceedingly old and yet are not gray-haired .

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — I and my likes grow not gray .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Will you tell me where I am ?

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — This is the cave by Kolbein 's stream . Thorolfshudders— I have heard it mentioned ! But what do you here ?

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — I gather shields for my roof .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Shields ?

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — Those that drop from the hands of men slain in battle . Thorolfin fear and wrath— You plunder the dead !

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — Mine are all the slain !

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Are you Woden , then , the father of all devils ?Draws his sword and strikes at him , but the blow strikes the roof of the cave .Jarngrimwho has not stirred while the blow was struck— Rarely avails the blow which is struck too high . Thorolfholds his shield before his body , with his sword behind it , and peers under the hood of JARNGRIM— You startled not !

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — But you have changed color . I never blink my eyes .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Yet it may go ill with but one eye , you evil spirit !

sp.speaker: Jarngrim
sp.p: — Many are the eyes of day , the night has but one ! Let not the fire die down , Thorolf ! The mead you will drink with me to-night has become warm ! Is well-nigh ready .

div.stage: JARNGRIM walks into the cave . As soon as his back is turned a black patch is seen between his shoulders . THOROLF strikes another blow at him , but his sword strikes the rock wall . JARNGRIM and the ravens vanish .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Is he hiding here , the hell-hound ? His Men — Who ? Who ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — I have spoken with Woden and he has foretold me my death .

sp.speaker: First Man
sp.p: — You have not spoken with any one , since we came here . But we have heard avalanches in the distance , nor is that strange in weather such as this .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — I shall live no longer than this fire burns ! Take well care of the fire , men ! Where are you , my men ?Falls into a swoon . The second man tends the fire and makes it blaze up ; the first man busies himself with THOROLF .

sp.speaker: Second Man
sp.p: — He is very ill .

sp.speaker: First Man
sp.p: — He may have seen some ill wight , for ever since he saw the fire he has lost his senses . Broddibehind the stage— There is that fire again , let us go that way .

sp.speaker: First Man
sp.p: — I heard some one speaking , a small distance away . Likely , they are no friends of Thorolf 's who are abroad .

sp.speaker: Second Man
sp.p: — And no water at hand to put out the fire , neither would it avail now . Brandwithout— None but fugitives will be here !

div.stage: Enter BRAND KOLBEINSSON , BRODDI , ALF , EINAR THE RICH , DEACON SIGURD , HELGI SKAFTASON , and six other men .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — What 's this ? Seize the men that cower over Thorolf .

div.stage: THOROLF 'S men are seized and disarmed .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — There he lies now , the lord of Eyafirth !

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — Strike the dog ! Thorolfregains his senses and stands up quickly— For shame , neighbor Alf ! Why do you seize upon my men and hold them ?

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — So that they may harm no one ! Now , Thorolf , it is our intention that this will be our last meeting .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — Death is before your door now , Thorolf .

lg.l: — ‘ The love of many girls had I ,
One time every one must die . ’
Did I see right ? Is Brand Kolbeinsson here ?

div.stage: Footnote A : These lines are from a stanza spoken by one Thorir Jokul , when kneeling for the blow ( Sturlunga , 143 ) .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: — Here he is .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — There is no glory in my overcoming such as you , Einar the Rich . But there , I want to get to where stands Brand Kolbeinsson .BRAND stands still while these words are exchanged ; some men stand between him and THOROLF . THOROLF rushes at BRAND , but the others fell him and wound him before he has reached BRAND .Now was I too short by one step . Einargiving THOROLF a wound— You have always despised me ! Thorolfgets upon his feet , but is held fast and made to surrender his arms— A priest I would now have , Broddi , in the name of God !

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — What will you with a priest , you heathen dog ?

lg.l: — All the more need . Go to him , Deacon Sigurd !
Sigurd
lg.stage: goes to THOROLF , whom the others release
lg.l: — You know ,
Thorolf , that I am a priest ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Give me absolution , priest , the same as if you were in my place ! My soul is in danger . I have spoken with Woden , but a short while ago . He said the ale was ready which we were to drink together to-night . For God 's sake absolve me well of my sins !

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — So shall it be . Thorolfto BRODDI— What will you have for my life ?

div.stage: BRODDI remains silent .

lg.l: — I offer you to leave the country and never come back to
Iceland .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — You must know , Thorolf , that you are to die . There is no other condition .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Each of you would consider himself too young to die already , if he were in my place now . You are keeping long your vow of everlasting truce , Brand Kolbeinsson !

div.stage: BRAND remains silent .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Those that keep it as you do ‘ shall shun churches and Christian people , the house of God and the houses of men and every home but hell ! ’ A great wonder it would be if you obtain the absolution of a priest in the hour of your death . I summon you before God , Brand Kolbeinsson !

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Lead the man away to be executed , Helgi Skaftason , you have a good axe .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — That I have ; nor shall I refuse its service .

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Helgi Skaftason is then to —!Quickly takes his ring off his wrist and comes close to SIGURD . EINAR happens to stand near so that he can discern their speech .Can you keep a secret , priest ?

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — That can every one who is in holy office . Thorolfgives him the ring and says in low voice— Quickly hide this ring and bring it to Lady Helga . Sigurddo— With what message ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — That you shall be spared life and limb , though you have been participant in this onslaught on me .EINAR gives a start .

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — And any others ?

sp.speaker: Thorolf
sp.p: — Little I care . Einaraside— That ring must I try to get hold of .

div.stage: THOROLF is led out to the left ; all the others follow , excepting BRODDI and BRAND .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — You must not be present at it , Brand ! I shall tell you what is happening . Now Thorolf is shriven ; he has but few sins to confess ; he has been absolved but recently .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — If they had not lit the fire we would never have found them . Better had it been they had not lit it !

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — A pity that brave men such as Thorolf was should not be good men to work together with , likewise . Now Thorolf kneels down for the blow . Do not look that way , Brand !

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Has he the crucifix in his hand ?

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — No ; he reached it to Deacon Sigurd , before kneeling down . Why does Helgi let a brave man wait so long for the blow ?

div.stage: A heavy blow on a body is heard without . BRAND starts up , pulls THOROLF 'S ring from his arm and gives it to BRODDI .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Give Helgi Skaftason this ring ; he will have need of the value in it . It is the ring Thorolf handed over to me in Flugumyr . I will not wear it !

lg.l: — It shall be as you wish . Now our men have laid a shield over
Thorolf 's body .

div.stage: The slayers of THOROLF enter from the left .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — Great news abroad !

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — We know what has happened , and that Thorolf Bjarnason is dead .

lg.l: — ‘ Dog-like on crushed bones he fed ,
Tan of bark his hide dyed red . ’

div.stage: Footnote A : Alf 's lines are to be understood , so that Thorolf lived like a beggar in his youth , eating crushed bones ( of dried fish ; the dried fish are beaten with a hammer so as to crush the bones and separate them from the meat ) , and gnawing the bark of trees . ( H . Hermannsson . ) The lines are from a stanza made by one Gudmund Asbjarnason on Thorolf Sturlunga , ch . 122 .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Shame on you , Alf , to make mock at Thorolf , now he is dead .

div.stage: Enter from the right LADY HELGA , ASBJORN , and SALVOR . HELGA in traveling costume , with a veil with long white tassels . All present are greatly alarmed as they see her .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Lady Helga ! Hail , cousin !

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Hail to all of you !They bow to her .What are you about , here , kinsman Brand ?

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — I am biding for better weather . But what may be the purpose of your journey ?

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — I am on a voyage to inspect our building of ships . In the snowstorm I and Asbjorn lost our way ; but a short while ago we saw a fire or a light and turned that way . Now we are come here .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — How fares Kolbein , your husband ?

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Very eager you are now to succeed to him .Smiles . THOROLF 'S men , weaponless , come running up and stop behind .You here !

sp.speaker: First Man
sp.p: — They have slain Thorolf Bjarnason . His body lies here ! Helgagrasps at her heart for a moment— Thorolf Bjarnason ! Slain !

sp.speaker: Second Man
sp.p: — But this moment they beheaded him .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — Oh , pity that I came too late !Shoves ASBJORN aside and fixes her eyes on those present .Who of you slew T-h-o-r-o-l-f ? Helgi Skaftasonadvances and dries his axe on the fringes of her veil ; she smiles at him— Here you may see the blood of Thorolf , your friend , my lady . Me you have to thank for it that his locks are bloody . Asbjornpushing forth between them— You wretched knave !

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Shame upon you , Helgi Skaftason !

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — What business of yours is it ?Smiling , to HELGI .You may depend upon me for rewarding you for the precious stain you have put on my veil . Not just now . I shall find you later , Helgi Skaftason ! Alfto BRODDI— She will bring a plague upon us all ; let us draw a sack over her head .A

div.stage: Footnote A : A measure taken against the influence of the ‘ evil eye ’ of witches .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — I shall kill you , Alf ! Helgato BRAND— Is it from our kinsmen at Oddi that you have learned how to keep an eternal truce , Brand , ‘ a truce which shall persist the while the earth lasts and men live ’ ?

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Lady !

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Brand Kolbeinsson had no part in Thorolf 's execution . Helgasmiling— Then it is clear he has kept the eternal truce . Perhaps neither you had a part in it , Broddi ?

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — I shall not deny that I had , lady .

sp.speaker: Helga
sp.p: — But little you know the mind of my husband , Broddi , if you think he will let his men lie dead by his house and unatoned . You , Asbjorn , and you , men of Thorolf 's , lay now his body upon my sleigh . I intend to bring Kolbein the Young , his friend . Very likely I shall have to dress his bloody locks . But that shall I say to you all that Kolbein the Young is almost quite well again , and may be able to wear mail even to-morrow .All are startled and become alarmed .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — Loose sits my head on its shoulders ! Helgasmiling— You will do well to hold it fast with both your hands , Alf of Grof .Aside to SALVOR .Lend me your arm ! My eyes grow dim !Exeunt HELGA , SALVOR , and ASBJORN , the two men of THOROLF . HELGA walks away like a queen , smiling , and saluting to both sides . Silence .Helgi Skaftasonleaning on his axe— But a short while will the hand rejoice over the blow .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — She smiled rather too often , the queen of the Northlanders !

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — We shall be dead men , all of us , before seven suns have set , unless we bethink ourselves of some counsel .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Give us some counsel , Broddi , or else my kinsman Kolbein will set our women busy dressing bloody locks also .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — We have but little choice . Let us collect as many men as we may . I myself hope to collect two hundred men , for all the men of Sletthlid and Fljot are at home now , building boats . Yourself ought to be able to collect one hundred . All this troop we shall let come together at Holar and occupy the stronghold there , until more men come together . We would then have three hundred men , while Kolbein has no more than one hundred , because three hundred of his men have been sent west to guard Vididal and Vatnsdal . Then we shall march upon Flugumyr as fast as possible before he has had time to recall these men . There we shall inform him that we are come to seek composition .

lg.l: — But , first of all , we must be absolved for the murder of
Thorolf , so that men will not refuse our company and deal with us .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — A pity that we need to , because it will delay us , and meanwhile Lady Helga will inform Kolbein about Thorolf 's death and egg him on against us . To Holar , then ! Einaraside— Thord Kakali ought to know about this in good time .

div.stage: Exeunt all except BRODDI and BRAND , who remain after .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — When think you , Broddi , that all this slaughtering and warring will cease ?

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — When all the world has become a wilderness again !Exeunt .Curtain . ACT III

div.stage: The Cathedral at Holar . High altar in the center , and over it Christ on the Cross , an image of white alabaster , with bloody hands and feet and side , life-size . To either side , in the aisles , altars of the Virgin , splendid with images . On the floor of the aisle the tombstone of Bishop Gudmund Arason , surmounted by a statue of the bishop in his sacerdotal vestments , recumbent . Doors at both sides . The spectator is supposed to sit in the pews .

BISHOP BOTOLF , in full pontificals , stands before the altar . BRAND KOLBEINSSON , BRODDI , ALF , DEACON SIGURD , EINAR THE RICH , HELGI SKAFTASON , and six others kneeling before him weaponless with bared neck and shoulders . An invisible chorus sings the end of a Miserere . The music stops as soon as the psalm is finished .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — By that power which God gave to the apostle Peter to bind and to absolve all in heaven as well as on earth , which power he bestowed upon the pope , and the pope upon the archbishop , and the archbishop upon me , by this power I absolve you : Brand Kolbeinsson , Broddi Thorleifsson , Alf Gudmundsson , Deacon Sigurd Thjodolfsson , Helgi Skaftason , Einar the Rich , and you six other men , from the sin of your having been present at and caused the death of Thorolf Bjarnason ; I absolve you from the excommunication of the Holy Church and permit to you church-going , and the association of Christian men .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — In return for our being freed from the excommunication of the Holy Church I and Broddi Thorleifsson each will give the value of five hundred in land , to the see of Holar ; and two hundred for each of those who were present at the slaying of Thorolf , as is set forth more explicitly in the deed of gift which I now deliver into your hands and which Deacon Sigurd worded .Gives the bishop a scroll of parchment . BRAND and his men rearrange their garments .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Exceeding bold have you become , Deacon Sigurd , to carry weapons and to shed blood .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — A weaponless man is but a wretch , my lord !

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — Armed priests went to war with Bishop Gudmund Arason , my lord !

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Because of his visitations with armed men , his battlings , and his unruliness Bishop Gudmund was declared to have forfeited his office .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — Yet retained his office as bishop till his dying day , through the good services of Kolbein the Young .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Kolbein is king over you all , yet archbishop , I know , he is not . Over my clerics I mean to rule so long as I am in power .

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — I did not urge on to Thorolf 's execution , and no sacraments would he have received had I not been one of the company .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — For that reason I shall let pass by your transgression , this once , but leave your weapons here , when you depart , and never more carry weapons henceforth .

sp.speaker: Sigurd
sp.p: — I shall obey , my lord ! Kolbein Kaldaljosenters— Now I would pray you , sir bishop , that you assist my son and his men to obtain a becoming reconciliation in the action about Thorolf 's death ; because my namesake Kolbein was a stanch friend of his .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Those who are reconciled with the Holy Church ought also to be reconciled with all Christian men .

lg.l: — They ought certainly ; but Kolbein the Young is but little of a
Christian when he means to take revenge for one of his men .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — He will perhaps call the slaying of Thorolf an act of insurrection against himself .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — It is an ill matter to assist rebels .

sp.speaker: Kolbein Kaldaljos
sp.p: — Thorolf insulted my son by giving him a nickname , and he took revenge for that .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — You Icelanders must be more deliberate in your words than are we Norwegians , if every nickname shall cost a man 's life . The slaying of Thorolf was a wicked deed , because Brand swore him an eternal truce . But in this land every one seems hardened in the ways of Kain .

sp.speaker: Kolbein Kaldaljos
sp.p: — My son Brand will succeed to Kolbein the Young !

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — He will succeed Kolbein ? Then shall I seek to bring about a reconciliation between you and Kolbein the Young !

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — And for the purpose that it come about in the smoothest manner possible I need the fortifications of your see a day or two for my men .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — You will be welcome to use them , Broddi .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — In still another matter give me assistance , sir bishop ! During the hostilities that have lasted all these years a certain man who was being led to execution summoned me before the tribunal of God .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — For that the Church knows no other help than a general indulgence and your living the rest of your natural life in peace .

sp.speaker: Brand
sp.p: — In peace ? How is that possible now ?

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Blessed peace ! when will you descend upon this blood-stained earth ? Broddismiling— You must call out louder , my lord , to do some good ! The blessed peace has been stricken with deafness these times .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Oh wicked mockery !

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Wicked indeed , if it were not true .

div.stage: The cleric HELGI enters quickly .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — Kolbein the Young is riding toward Holar at this moment , with a hundred men .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — Let us flee to the mountains .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Let us wait for my brother-in-law Kolbein at this spot .

sp.speaker: Alf
sp.p: — He will have us dragged out of the church and killed .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — I shall not flee with my shield on my back .

lg.l: — No , friend Broddi , we shall not part as yet .
lg.stage: Seizes hold of BRODDI , whom they drag out by force between them .

sp.speaker: Broddi
sp.p: — Why run away thus ? I care not when I die .

div.stage: BRAND and his eleven companions depart , together with KOLBEIN KALDALJOS .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — Now they will offer you violence , my lord .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — I expect no harm from Kolbein the Young , no wrong have I done in this land , but only what all may thank me for , and that is to reconcile the chieftains .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — But it was in your presence that Gizur betrayed Urækja at the bridge over the White River .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — But Kolbein released Urækja again !

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — Much do you say in defence of Kolbein the Young ; the enemy of our sainted Bishop Gudmund Arason , my father-brother . Now the blessed bishop has revealed himself to me in a dream and announced that at this very hour he would make known his glory and power , right here in the church , through a miracle on Illugi , a wretched blind man . I wish much that Kolbein should behold it , so that he might repent of his ill deeds against this holy man . A miraculum magnum will come to pass !

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Nothing , indeed , would so much allay Kolbein 's violence as the holiness of Bishop Gudmund becoming apparent . It would make him ready for reconciliation , should he behold that he used ill so great a saint . But are you so very sure that the see of Holar really possessed such a holy man in Bishop Gudmund ?

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — Most certainly , indeed !Exit .Botolfalone— Bishop Gudmund a saint ? Notwithstanding all the slayings and destruction that followed in his wake ? Bishop Gudmund a saint , hm ! He who used to speak a blessing over mad dogs , with his hands uplifted ! Bishop Gudmund a saint , hm ! Well , then would the church indeed be victorious over Kolbein the Young and his men .

div.stage: Enter KOLBEIN THE YOUNG , HAF , and ASBJORN . They salute the bishop , who returns their greetings .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — I have come hither , sir bishop , to confer with you .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — With whom then do all those your men wish to confer , and what mean the arms you carry into the church ?

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Tumult and riot is rife in the district .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — But a few days ago I expected to hear of your death , Kolbein , rather than see you here heading a host of men .

sp.speaker: Asbjorn
sp.p: — Does it not suit you , my lord ?

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — I desire the death of no man .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — For a while I was very sick , indeed ; but no sooner heard I of the death of my friend Thorolf than all weakness left me , so that now I am a well man again .

div.stage: Enter CLERK HELGI , ILLUGI THE BLIND MAN , and HIS BOY , who supports him . People stream in with them , stationing themselves in the doors and near them . CLERK HELGI makes ILLUGI kneel down before the sepulchre of BISHOP GUDMUND , so that he turns his face to the spectators .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — Kneel down now before the sepulchre of the sainted friend of God who appeared to you in your dream ; because your prayers have made you deserving of that beatitude . Embrace the image of our blessed father and say the Lord 's prayer .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Is that man blind ? Illugilooks up and glances at him for a moment— I am born blind . Kolbeinaside to HAF BJARNASON— His eyes were fixed on me as he looked up .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — Domine Gudmunde , fac miraculum magnum ! Illugimutters— Pater noster !

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — Behold the white hand of the saint , how it draws the film from the eyes of the blind man !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — I have not the gift to see such things .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — Oh ye of little faith ! Some at the Door .— I smell sweet fragrance . I see a tongue of fire above the tombstone of Bishop Gudmund !

sp.speaker: Others
sp.p: — He was good to the poor ! Illugiwith a loud voice , lifting up his crutch and arising— Praised be the blessed Bishop Gudmund ! My eyes can see !

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — O miraculum magnum ! The People at the Doors .— A miracle ! A miracle ! A miracle !

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Let all bells of the church be rung .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Wait an instant , my lord ! The eyes of the man are unchanged . Let him prove that he can see .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — Ay , let him do that , my lord ! Let the man prove that he can see , so that Thomas be made to believe . Kolbeinaside— Hand me a parchment , Haf !HAF takes a scroll out of a box in the choir and reaches it over to him .You were blind , then , when I spoke to you before ?

sp.speaker: Illugi
sp.p: — I am born blind , my lord ! But now it seems to me I can see all that others see .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — I have still my doubts about thatholding the parchment before ILLUGIAre you able to see what this is ?

sp.speaker: Illugi
sp.p: — A parchment , my lord .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — And can you discern what is there written ?

sp.speaker: Illugi
sp.p: — I can see the letters clearly .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — That you could say , although you could not see them . Illugireads— ‘ And when St. John was arrayed in his pontifical robes , ready for burial — ’

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — How is it possible that you who are born blind have learned to read ?

div.stage: ILLUGI remains silent , greatly frightened .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — O miraculum magnum ! Holy Bishop Gudmund has imparted to him the art of reading !

sp.speaker: Illugi
sp.p: — The glorious saint appeared to me last night in a dream and taught me to read , so that I might prove to-day that my eyes can see .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — In that case more forethought was shown by Bishop Gudmund than he was accustomed to show when he was alive .

div.stage: BISHOP BOTOLF becomes uneasy ; KOLBEIN 's men look at each other smiling .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — The revelation of the saintliness of Holy Bishop Gudmund has affected me so much , my lord , that I forgot to have all the bells of the church rung .Intends to leave .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Wait with that a little while , Helgi .

sp.speaker: Haf
sp.p: — They will ring of themselves when the time has come .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Where are you from ?

div.stage: ILLUGI remains silent , as to all following questions . The boy always looks at him first before answering , making reply only when he sees that ILLUGI remains silent .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Where are you two from ?

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: — From the Hornstrands , my lord !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — What was Thord Kakali about when you left ?

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: — We do not know , my lord !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — You must have remained over night at Bolstadarhlid before you ascended the Vatnsskard .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: — We did , my lord !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Did yeoman Jon send me no message by you ?

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: — No , my lord , yeoman Jon sent no message by us .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — You must be a clever and trusty lad , though you are young .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: — You give me high praise , my lord , and it is good to hear .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — You are careful to ask men about their names , or get to know them from others . That is doing well for a young lad .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: — I asked yeoman Jon myself what his name was , my lord !

lg.l: — There you lied again , little boy . The yeoman at
Bolstadarhlid is called Thorvard Arnason .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — You lied in that yourself , Kolbein , to say that the yeoman 's name was Jon . The boy would never have dared to ask the yeoman about his name . Kolbeinto HAF— Seize hold of this man and bring him into the prison at Flugumyr . Bishop Gudmund will open its doors for him if time hangs heavy on his hands there .ILLUGI the blind man runs out , forgetting his crutches ; the people follow him . One hears the multitude outside shouting , ‘ A miracle ’ .Asbjornto HELGI— Was it Bishop Gudmund or Kolbein the Young who made that man forget his crutches ?

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: — If Kolbein has done it , then has he done it by the help of Beelzebub .He gathers up the crutches . HAF and ASBJORN follow him as he leaves the church .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Did you have a part in this farce , my lord ?

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — No , my lord !Mutters .Pia fraus , pia fraus !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Then all is well . Bishop Gudmund was a witless man , but no saint .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — That is without example in Christendom how you laymen of Iceland treated Bishop Gudmund ; you killed his men and his clerks , went to battle against him , beat and bound him , and in no wise let him enjoy peace .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Bishop Gudmund was a scourge upon the land . On his journeys he devoured the property of one farmer in the morning , and of another in the evening .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Finally you deprived him even of his freedom .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — That was the very best thing for him !

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Such conduct on your part violated God 's laws .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — But not the laws of this land , sir bishop . They say , ‘ But if a man have a savage dog , then shall this dog be kept bound . ’ And I took the dog and bound him , sir bishop !

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — The property of the church it was that tempted you , and not the laws of the land ; and how have you atoned for your robbery ?

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — With my and Thorolf Bjarnason 's pilgrimage to Rome .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — And with the help of this property of the church you have set yourself in the place of that man who alone had divine right to the land .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — His is the land who holds it .

lg.l: — The king of Norway lays claim to all the land settled by
Norwegians .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — The fewest of the settlers on Iceland 's soil were subjects of the king of Norway . For that matter , why comes not King Hakon and take the land from us ?

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Because many hands would be raised in its defence , and the king wishes the land to remain in peace .

lg.l: — No one has caused more feuds among us Icelanders than has
King Hakon . All feuds arose through his devices .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Raise the banner of King Hakon in this land , Kolbein !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Who would bear the banner for that coward ? No , but should the king come hither you will see me take up a banner ; but it will not be that of King Hakon !

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — In order to bring the land under the king 's dominion you would need but to ride to the king with twelve hundred men and let all the assembly swear an oath of allegiance to the king . Both bishops would stand back of you in that undertaking .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Norwegians both !

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — The archbishop has written me that the king would raise you to the highest rank among Icelanders if you did that .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — What I am already I need not become by the grace of Hakon .

lg.l: — He would give you an earl 's rank and set you over all
Iceland .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — They gave Snorri Sturluson an earl 's name , and the king became the contriver of his death .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — The archbishop writes that the king would make you highest commander among his forces , if you should prefer that . Kolbeinrejoiced at first , but quickly controls himself— Is that written in the archbishop 's letter ? Botolftaking out a scroll of parchment— Here you may read it !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Leader of the Birchlegs !AThat is a goodly army ! No , for that my health suffices no more — they all are brisk men ! Tell the archbishop that even if I were always in good health I would think it a nobler thing to do battle against the Birchlegs than with them .

div.stage: Footnote A : The name of the Norwegian king Sverre 's hardy soldiers .

lg.l: — You are the only Icelander who hates Norway and its king ,
Kolbein !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — I remember too well that my father died in Norway an enemy of the king and the archbishop . At that time I was thirteen years and dull it seemed to me in Norway thereafter .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — If such is the case , Gizur and Thord Kakali will stretch out both their hands after the honors you now turn your back upon . Gizur has already received honors from the king .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — I recall that Gizur has become his link-boy . It is strange that he wanted to snuff candles for Kakon .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Gizur holds lands from the king and is his kinsman .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Whatever the king may make of my kinsman Gizur , I know for sure that he will never be able to give him the courage to take up arms against me .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — But he might go so far as to let Thord Kakali have his men , and Thord would dare to fight with you .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — He does indeed ! I shall have to kill Thord before mid-summer !

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — True is the saying that no chieftain in Iceland lays himself down to sleep any day without danger !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — We are mortal men , we chieftains .

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — Will Gizur also have to be made a head shorter before mid-summer , Kolbein , should he come to Iceland ?

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — Who can know what the future will bring , sir bishop ?

div.stage: ASBJORN and HAF enter in headlong haste .

sp.speaker: Asbjorn
sp.p: — There is prospect of tidings ; Broddi Thorleifsson comes riding down the valley with two hundred armed men . Kolbeinwrathfully , to the BISHOP— What seeks my cousin Broddi at Holar with two hundred men ?

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — The peace of the land seems insecure to him and he is coming hither for defending himself in the fort .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — You encourage men to rebellion against me , you devil in a bishop 's guise ! Is that the peace the king and the archbishop intend to bring to the land ?

sp.speaker: Botolf
sp.p: — What means this wrath in God 's church ?

sp.speaker: Haf
sp.p: — What council shall we take , Kolbein ? Broddi is advancing rapidly .

sp.speaker: Kolbein
sp.p: — You , Asbjorn , will cross the mountains with a dozen men and advise my wife Helga to draw all guards from the west as fast as is at all possible . You yourself will continue your journey south over the Kjol to Hjalti , the son of the bishop to come north at once with all the men he can summon , to prevent difficulties here .

sp.speaker: Asbjorn
sp.p: — Indeed , a strenuous journey , now at the height of winter !

sp.speaker: Kolbein
